# Threat Intelligence Report: The Evolution of Doppel Spider from BitPaymer to Grief Ransomware In this report, Armor's Amer Elsad will dive deep and explore Grief operation and development since it was first observed in July 2017 as BitPaymer, as well as compare the different variants and partnerships with other threat actors and ransomware groups

The report contains information about how threat actors have evolved their tactics from spam campaigns targeting victims based on geolocation data to more sophisticated attacks leveraging compromised credentials as well as social engineering lures. This document also provides details about new tools being developed by attackers such as "Doppel Spider," which can stealthily infect computers without users noticing any activity.

The final stage of operation involves loading a legitimate Windows executable into memory as if it were running on disk. This allows the attacker to execute arbitrary code without having access to any system resources. In order to avoid detection, the loader will not load itself directly; instead, it loads another file called `DllMain` which contains the actual entry point. Once loaded, the main function will call back into its own implementation of `InitializeCriticalSection`, ensuring that only one instance of the process can run at once. If there is no other instance already running, then execution continues normally.

These actions allow them to remain undetected while executing their next stage.

A possible use after free could occur when a process allocates more than one page of virtual memory space on disk. This can lead to incorrect data being written into those pages causing them to become unmappable. If there were no other errors present, then the system would continue running normally without any problems. However if another error occurred such as a crash, the operating system will not allow further execution until all previously allocated memory has been freed up.

In AWS, you cannot enable access control rules to prevent unauthorized access to the EC2 instance metadata. Instead, you can adopt some strategies that limit the risks associated with AWS credential theft: - If your instance doesn't need to have access to metadata, it should be disabled. This minimizes the attack surface and avoids AWS credentials theft. - You can also replace the default IMDSv1 method with the newer IMDSv2 for accessing instance metadata
In AWS, you can only set up Access Control Lists (ACL). This means if someone tries to get into your account they will need permission from another user before being able to do so.

To evade network-based IDS, we use two different methods. First, we create fake files on disk which contain legitimate file names such as `C:\Windows\System32\drivers\` and then copy them into `%TEMP%`. Second, we set up a scheduled task named "Microsoft Windows Defender Evasion Tool." This tool will run every time you start your computer. It creates a new folder called "%temp%" under %USERPROFILE%. Whenever Microsoft Windows Defender detects any suspicious activity from our system, it will delete all these folders and their contents.

Modification of the Thread Object's PreviousMode Field The PreviousMode field is a field that verifies in the kernel whether the thread object has been called from the user area. In order to modify the PreviousMode field, the rootkit used the virtual address-physical address conversion code and physical kernel memory mapping to change the PreviousMode field value from "1" to "0". Intel PT records code execution on the processor and is often used for performance diagnosis and analysis. Intel PT allows the CPU to continuously write information about the currently executing code into a memory buffer, which can be used to reconstruct the exact control flow. The primary usage scenario is to trace an executable while it runs, store the trace on the disk, and afterward analyze it to reproduce the exact sequence of instructions that has been executed. A legitimate Windows executable file named reader_sl.exe has been injected into another process (`mshta`/`wmia`). This injection uses PowerShell code to execute the original process asynchronously from its own thread. It then calls GetProcessThreadIdW() on the newly created child process to retrieve the current user ID. Next, it creates a new thread which will wait until the parent process terminates before executing the next step. Finally, it executes the shellcode stored inside the memory space allocated by the previous steps.

Supply Chain Exploitation: The attackers targeted the software supply chain by: 1. Compromising a third-party software update server used by multiple victim organizations 2. Injecting malicious code into legitimate software updates 3. Exploiting vulnerabilities in commonly used open-source libraries 4. Targeting developers with spear-phishing attacks to gain access to source code repositories 5. Implementing a backdoor in a popular software development kit (SDK) used by target organizations

The supply chain has been compromised due to vulnerabilities in Microsoft Office products such as Word, Excel, PowerPoint, etc. This can lead to data exfiltration from victims who use these applications on their network.

Kwampirs uses a large list of C2 servers that it cycles through until a successful connection is established

A Kwampiri server has been detected on one of its C2 servers. It will use another domain name as a proxy when connecting to other domains. This technique allows attackers to hide their true location from security tools such as DNSSEC.
